Award.AwardTitle: A Cultural and Linguistic Anthropological Analysis of Youth Language Socialization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Shalini Shankar of Northwestern University will study child language socialization through the exploration of contests that are focused on ritualized learning. This project will employ cultural and linguistic anthropological methodologies to investigate how ritualized learning contests contribute to processes of child socialization, language commodification, and the production of identities and racial imagery in the contemporary United States. It addresses these questions: 1) How do children and parents participate together in socialization rituals learn specialized ways of speaking, relevant vocal and visualization techniques, and embodied practices to excel at spelling bees? 2) How has the increased commercialization of these contests through corporate branding and prime-time broadcasting transformed this language education exercise into a mass mediated, sport-like spectacle? 3) How are the youth who succeed subject to scrutiny and characterizations that contribute to overall meanings about immigration, race, and the English language? Data will be collected via observations, audio recordings, video taping, and interviews: at three organizations that produce these events the latter two of which are exclusively for South Asian Americans; at select regional and national events; and in childrens' (ages 6-14) homes to document their preparation practices and intergenerational relationships. Interviews will be conducted with children, their parents, coaches, spelling bee organizers, pronouncers, judges, corporate sponsors, and media broadcasters. Data will be analyzed to consider the significance of the everyday acquisition and on-stage execution of socialization to broader debates of socioeconomics, language, race, and media.

The project will contribute to several contemporary anthropological debates about language and socioeconomic change, by offering broader insights about the commodification of the English language and new roles for English in globalizing economies; youth, language, and socialization, by exploring new perspectives on new paradigms of child learning and socialization; and media, race, and language, by providing fine-grained empirical data about how broadcast media and racial ideologies coalesce in the reinforcement of stereotypes about race, immigration, and English language standardization.

Project broader impacts will occur as follows: 1) several scholarly articles and a monograph; 2) at least two articles written in clear, jargon-free prose aimed at K-12 educators and the general public; 3) the on-site methodological training of undergraduate and graduate students; the PI will guide students in conducting ethnographic observations and interviews with subjects of different ages; 4) the creation of a free, child-friendly, website developed from project data; this educational intervention will address inequities in preparation materials and adult mentoring by advancing learning techniques, including a "tutor" function that will quiz children when adults are unavailable; and 5) the use of recordings, transcripts, and other project data for linguistic and cultural anthropology teaching and mentoring.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Shalini Shankar of Northwestern University studied how childhood is transforming through contemporary forms of linguistic and cultural learning. Her research focused on “Generation Z,” born after 1997, to understand some of the day-to-day educational and social activities kids today undertake. Her research employed anthropological methodologies of ethnographic fieldwork and sociolinguistic analysis to examine how youth prepare for and participate in the National Spelling Bee and other competitions. Taking a longitudinal approach over several years, between 2013-2018, her research findings illustrate how these ritualized learning contests contribute to processes of child socialization, to intensified competition, and allow us to understand the impact of immigrant parenting on a broader cohort of young people in the United States. She followed children and youth she initially met at spelling bees and observed their activities and interests as they progressed toward high school and college.

The research findings are described briefly below, and elaborated on through interviews, narratives, and ethnographic observations in Shankar’s forthcoming book Beeline: What Spelling Bees Reveal about Generation Z’s New Path to Success (Basic Books, 2019). This book is written in clear, jargon-free prose, and is accessible to K-12 educators, educated parents, advanced middle schoolers, and young people in high school and college. A more anthropological treatment of topics including language and materiality, language commodification, sensoria, semiotics, and the language ideologies underpinning competitive spelling bees can be found in the various journal articles and book chapters. Further, de-identified data collected for this project has been used to train undergraduate and graduate students in cultural and linguistic anthropology.

The research findings span three primary areas, each of which considers aspects of language use and cultural practices. The first finding reports a shift in the nature of childhood, specifically, the ways childhood is now lived far more publically. Shankar studied the ways spellers managed media interviews and presented themselves for live television appearances, noting the pre-professional approach they took to this activity. Successful spellers often went on to participate in other endeavors, including tutoring for high wages, using technology to self-promote and conduct business, and other formations previously unavailable to middle school and high school kids, including start-up incubators for new companies formed with other youth. She also observed the social media practices of spellers, adding depth and texture to their widely accepted status as “digital natives.”

The second area is the increased dynamic of competition that marks childhood today. Gen Z kids in Shankar’s study were atypical in many ways, as they were identified for participation after they had advanced to a highly prestigious national contest. That said, the competition and drive that they exhibit seems to be becoming a part of their generational culture. Some Gen Z kids noted wanting to differentiate themselves from Millennials by being more self-directed, socially active, and success-oriented. Whereas the latter group is thought to live by an “everybody gets a trophy” approach to competition, Gen Z kids exhibit what social psychologists have called “grit.” Grit emphasizes hard work and repetition over extraordinary talent, and explains how some young people wish to be nationally recognized for their accomplishments, on a scale previously not seen among middle school and high school kids.

The third area examines the importance of ethnic and racial diversity vis-à-vis new waves of immigration. Generation Z contains more children of immigrants than any other, and is the most racially diverse. My study examined South Asian American immigrants in particular, noting the impact of other minorities as well, on the way areas of childhood being treated in a more professional manner. The implications of these parenting practices are contributing to a shift in what is expected and normal in childhood. Whereas once a time of play and exploration, at least in the white middle class imagination, it can now be a period of high accomplishment, notoriety, and professional gain.

Overall, the project presents a view of the bellwethers of America’s newest generational cohort. It is important to note that these kids are not typical or average. Yet, the directions signaled by these competitors is in concert with other reports about intense childhood competitions in a variety of areas, including dance, music, robotics, science fairs, chess, travel sports, and other areas. Like the National Spelling Bee, these activites have likelwise transformed dramatically over the last decade or so, making childhood today a very different endeavor than it was for past generations.

The project also contributes to several contemporary anthropological debates about language and socioeconomic change, by offering broader insights about the commodification of the English language and new roles for English in globalizing economies; youth, language, and socialization, by exploring new perspectives on child learning and socialization; and immigration and parenting, by providing fine-grained empirical data about how skilled immigrants are creating ripples of change in childhood activity, beyond their own families.
